text: 1. BRAHMA was the first of the Devas, the maker of the universe, the preserver of the world. He told the knowledge of Brahman, the foundation of all knowledge, to his eldest son Atharva 1 .

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 2. Whatever Brahmâ told Atharvan, that knowledge of Brahman Atharvan formerly told to Aṅgir; he told it to Satyavâha Bhâradvâ g a, and Bhâradvâ g a told it in succession to Aṅgiras.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 3. S aunaka, the great householder, approached Aṅgiras respectfully and asked: 'Sir, what is that through which, if it is known, everything else becomes known?'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 4. He said to him: 'Two kinds of knowledge must be known, this is what all who know Brahman tell us, the higher and the lower knowledge.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 5. 9 The lower knowledge is the Ri g-veda, Ya g ur-veda, Sâma-veda, Atharva-veda, S ikshâ (phonetics), Kalpa (ceremonial), Vyâkara n a (grammar), Nirukta (etymology), Kh andas (metre), G yotisha (astronomy) 2 ;

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: but the higher knowledge is that by which the Indestructible (Brahman) is apprehended.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 6. 'That which cannot be seen, nor seized, which has no family and no caste 1 , no eyes nor ears, no hands nor feet, the eternal, the omnipresent (all-pervading), infinitesimal, that which is imperishable, that it is which the wise regard as the source of all beings.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 7. 'As the spider sends forth and draws in its thread, as plants grow on the earth, as from every man hairs spring forth on the head and the body, thus does everything arise here from the Indestructible.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 8. 'The Brahman swells by means of brooding (penance) 2 ; hence is produced matter (food); from matter breath 3 , mind, the true 4 , the worlds (seven), and from the works (performed by men in the worlds), the immortal (the eternal effects, rewards, and punishments of works).'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 9. 'From him who perceives all and who knows all, whose brooding (penance) consists of knowledge, from him (the highest Brahman) is born that Brahman 1 , name, form 2 , and matter (food).'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 27:1 The change between Atharva and Atharvan, like that between Na k iketas and Nâ k iketa, shows the freedom of the phraseology of the Upanishad, and cannot be used for fixing the date of the constituent elements of the Upanishad.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 27:2 Other MSS. add here itihâsa-purâ n a-nyâya-mîmâ m sâ-dharma- s âstrâ n i.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 28:1 I translate var n a by caste on account of its conjunction with gotra. The commentator translates, 'without origin and without qualities.' We should say that which belongs to no genus or species.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 28:2 I have translated tapas by brooding, because this is the only word in English which combines the two meanings of warmth and thought. Native authorities actually admit two roots, one tap, to burn, the other tap, to meditate; see commentary on Parâ s ara-sm ri ti, p. 39 b (MS. Bodl.), Tapa h kri k kh ra k andrâya n âdirûpe n âhâravar g anam. Nanu Vyâsena tapo 'nyathâ smaryate, tapa h svadharma-vartitva m sau k a m saṅganibarha n am iti; nâya m dosha h , kri k kh râder api svadharmavi s eshât. Tapa sa m tâpa ity asmâd dhâtor utpannasya tapa h - s abdasya deha s osha n e v ri ttir mukhyâ. . . . Yat tu tatraivokta m , ko 'yam moksha h katha m tena sa m sâram pratipannavân ity âlo k anam artha g ñ âs tapa h sa m santi pa n d itâ iti so 'nya eva tapa h s abda h , tapa âlo k ana ity asmâd dhâtor utpanna h .

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 28:3 Hira n yagarbha, the living world as a whole. Comm.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 28:4 Satya, if we compare Ka th . VI, 7 and III, 10, seems to mean buddhi. Here it is explained by the five elements.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 29:1 Hira n yagarbha. Comm.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 29:2 Nâmarûpam, a very frequent concept in Buddhistic literature.
